reasoning: The critique targets a central pillar of the essay’s relative optimism—section 3’s claim that partial AM-convergence plus bargaining/trade can often get us to mostly-great futures. If pre-bargaining irreversible moves are systematically incentivized, then the essay’s ‘trade at the relevant period of bargaining’ picture is substantially weakened. However, the essay already flags early lock-in, timing sensitivity, power concentration, and institutional prerequisites as important blockers, so the critique partly reinforces rather than newly refutes. The argument is plausible (irreversibility and disagreement-point manipulation are real bargaining dynamics) but not fully developed into a decisive refutation (it asserts dominance of preemption without specifying conditions, equilibria, or why institutions/credible commitment couldn’t arise). It is mostly correct, clearly stated, tightly focused, and contains little-to-no filler.
title: Irreversible cosmic actions may preempt the bargaining the paper assumes
